title: How to write ''Japan'' in Japanese - Quora

response.answer_text: In Japanese kana, we pronounce the word にほん, or in romaji, Nihon. In kanji, 日本 (p. 474) is two syllables (when together). The character is a combination of the sun, to the left, and the tree (to the right). The kanji can be examined predicated on its taxonomy and associated with the composition of the two radicals, 72 日 (p. 473), pronounced hi or nichi (day) and 2, | pronounced bo (p. 55). 日, pronounced here, hi, means sun, time, day, date (p. 473). Radical 2, bo | (p. 55), has its roots as a single vertical line | and is referred to as a rod, a stick, or a line. Four additional strokes or lines are added to the initial single line | to create the kanji 本 (p. 64) , identified in Nelson’s Dictionary’s subsection 96, as within the category of radical 2, 本 (hon), and can mean book, real, the same, present, the current, true, and normal. Hon, 本 (p. 64), is also the counter for long things. The Modern Reader's Japanese-English Character Dictionary. Second revised edition by Andrew Nathaniel Nelson (there are any number of copyright dates). Published by Charles E. Tuttle, Co. Inc. Tokyo. A newer dictionary is The New Nelson Japanese-English Character Dictionary.

It’s “日本“ Assuming you’re trying to ask how to type it via a phone’s keyboard just open up the Japanese keyboard, and type ‘ni hon’ and it should come out. If not then you can also try typing ‘nippon’ which is another way of saying Japan.
